Boaz Weinstein Hedge Fund Spars With BlackRock and Neuberger

Saba is embroiled in fights over closed-end fund boards with asset managers and law firm Skadden

By Rachael Levy

Wall Street Journal

Aug. 28, 2019 7:06 pm ET

New York hedge fund Saba Capital Management LP is currently embroiled in separate fights with two large Wall Street asset managers and a well-known law firm over the obscure mechanics of closed-end fund boards.

In one dispute, Boaz Weinstein’s Saba Capital sued BlackRock Inc., BLK 0.81% arguing that the world’s largest asset manager tried to block outsiders from gaining board seats at three of its funds and effecting change. The Delaware Chancery Court ruled in Saba’s favor in June on two of the funds. A Maryland court ruled in favor of BlackRock on a third fund, a BlackRock spokesman said. The two firms have ongoing litigation.

In another dispute, Saba recently proposed changes at a Neuberger Berman Group LLC closed-end fund in which it owns shares. In response, Neuberger Berman fought the propositions and alleged a fund run by Saba is violating securities laws.

Saba, a $1.7 billion hedge fund, is an investor in many closed-end funds.

Such funds hold securities and, like exchange-traded funds, are listed on exchanges. But while ETF share prices typically track the price of the underlying securities, closed-end funds often don’t. Saba is an activist investor, buying up large positions in funds with low prices and trying to force changes, such as overhauling the board. The fund operators often resist.

Frank J. Abella Jr., a decadeslong investor in closed-end funds and the chief executive of Investment Partners Group, said the dispute has potentially high stakes.

If Saba prevails, “this industry is going to be shaken to its core,” he said. “The line is drawn in the sand.”
